Given the varied outlook, management plans to continue the progress of the last few years in strengthening the Company's financial position by further reducing debt. A strengthened balance sheet will mitigate risk while allowing the ongoing and planned operational and capital investments. These investments are necessary to continue the strong growth in a number of the Company's businesses that are creating real shareholder value. Management would like to thank the entire Glacier staff and our partners for their continued dedication and hard work. The results and ongoing transformation and strengthening of the business is due to their efforts. We would also like to thank our Board of Directors for their valuable guidance and support over the past year. Shares in Glacier are traded on the Toronto Stock Exchange under the symbol GVC. About the Company: Glacier Media Inc. is an information & marketing solutions company pursuing growth in sectors where the provision of essential information and related services provides high customer utility and value. Glacier's strategy is implemented through two operational areas: content and marketing solutions; and data, analytics and intelligence. Financial Measures To supplement the consolidated financial statements presented in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards, Glacier uses certain non-IFRS measures that may be different from the performance measures used by other companies. These non-IFRS measures include cash flow from operations (before changes in non-cash operating accounts and non-recurring items), net income attributable to common shareholders before non-recurring items, net income from continuing operation attributable to common shareholders before non-recurring items, earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) and all 'adjusted' measures which are not alternatives to IFRS financial measures. Management focuses on operating cash flow per share as the primary measure of operating profitability, free cash flow and value. EBITDA per share is also an important measure as the Company has low ongoing capital expenditures and depreciation and amortization largely relates to acquisition goodwill and copyrights and does not represent a corresponding sustaining capital expense. These non-IFRS measures do not have any standardized meanings prescribed by IFRS and accordingly they are unlikely to be comparable to similar measures presented by other issuers. The adjusted consolidated financial results have been adjusted to include the Company's share of revenue, expenses, assets and liabilities from its joint venture operations on a proportionate accounting basis as this is the basis on which management bases its operating decisions and performance evaluation. IFRS does not allow for the inclusion of the joint ventures on a proportionate basis. These results include additional non-IFRS measures such as EBITDA, cash flow from operations and net income attributable to common shareholders before non-recurring items. The adjusted results are not generally accepted measures of financial performance under IFRS. The Company's method of calculating these financial performance measures may differ from other companies and accordingly, they may not be comparable to measures used by other companies. Refer to the MD&A for a reconciliation of these non-IFRS measures and adjusted results. title: Largest personal donation in Alberta colleges' history to create Smart Agriculture hub
article: OLDS, AB, March 27, 2017 /CNW/ - Acclaimed Canadian entrepreneur, oilfield industry leader and dedicated philanthropist, David P. Werklund and his partner, Susan Norman, have gifted Olds College with $16M, the largest ever personal donation to an Alberta college or technical institution. The tiered donation will have a total cumulative impact of $32M when all leverage opportunities can be realized. Werklund's donation begins with $2M in cash, supplemented by a matching component where Werklund will provide one dollar for every three raised, up to $4M. The final element is a $10M estate gift that will ensure the sustainability of the institute over time. The donation is designed to incent maximum participation and donations from other individuals, industry and governments. This transformational gift will result in the creation of the Werklund Agriculture Institute (WAI) and will specialize in Smart Agriculture. With a vision to be the  world's premier destination for an integrated agricultural leadership learning experience, the WAI will engage students, researchers and industry in smart and sustainable agriculture and agri-business solutions, leadership and education to contribute to Western Canada's leadership position as an agriculture and food powerhouse. "Mr. Werklund and Ms. Norman's generous donation will accelerate engagement, innovation and technology adoption within the agriculture and food industry, and open up new agriculture enterprise in Alberta and around the world," commented Olds College president, Dr. H.J (Tom) Thompson. Momentum began to build when two additional donations were announced at the Olds College Gala on March 24. The Students' Association of Olds College and the Olds College Alumni Association have each committed $1.25M toward the Beyond campaign, to kick off the matching component of the Werklund donation. The Werklund Agriculture Institute will feature four key components: *Werklund Growth Centre - will provide a Hub for companies, entrepreneurs, investors and students to access Olds College land and facilities for development, scale up and demonstration of Smart Agriculture technologies, products and services. *Thought Leader in Smart Agriculture and Sustainability - a unique, fully endowed industry leader to serve as a connector, and advisor on smart agriculture technology, innovation and business for accelerating company growth and access to capital. *A Producer Mentor Program - a year-long partnership with Producers and Agriculture industry leaders, exposing students to Smart Agriculture practices. *Olds College Agriculture and Food Enterprise - a vertically integrated "gate to plate" agriculture and food learning enterprise where students engage in business decision making and management. Werklund's upbringing on a rural Alberta farm instilled in him a deep respect for protecting and nurturing the land which sustains life through food production and job creation. He credits his success in business, strong work ethic and core values with that upbringing as well. "Susan and I are thrilled to lead the way in support of this made-in-Alberta solution for specialized education, research and partnerships in Smart Agriculture," commented Werklund. "Our vision is that students will experience a world class education centered around best practices in smart and sustainable agriculture - practices that are environmentally responsible, fully leverage current technologies and ignite their passion for agriculture." About Smart Agriculture Smart Agriculture is the optimization of technology and science for the efficient and sustainable use of land and water for economic and environmental benefit.  It supports integrated, 'learning' in precision, data driven agriculture and food production systems by utilizing big data, technology and enhanced internet connectivity to increase the quality and quantity of agricultural production.  About Olds College Olds College is the premier Canadian integrated learning and applied research community specializing in agriculture, horticulture, land and environmental management. Olds College first opened its doors in November of 1913, and now includes programming that covers Animal Sciences, Horticulture, Land & Water, Fashion, Business, Hospitality & Tourism, and Trades & Apprenticeships. About the Beyond campaign The multi-year $40M fundraising campaign, Beyond, will fund several infrastructure projects designed to take the Olds College campus and its students beyond tomorrow, beyond expectations and beyond the classroom. SOURCE Olds College

title: Eurocontrol's Xenemetrix to Introduce PMetrix at 2017 American Chemical Society Spring Conference, San Francisco
article: Release date - 23032017 TORONTO, ONTARIO - Eurocontrol Technics Group Inc. a Canadian public company specializing in the acquisition, development and commercialization of innovative test and measurement technologies for industry with application systems focused on the energy security, semiconductor and precision farming sectors, is pleased to announce that its wholly owned subsidiary Xenemetrix Ltd. ('Xenemetrix') will be presenting its diverse lines of X-ray fluorescence (XRF) instrumentation at the 2017 ACS Spring Conference being held April 3rd through April 6th at the Moscone Convention Center in San Francisco, California. American Chemical Society (ACS) National Meetings provide researchers with current scientific, professional and product information news through various poster sessions, exhibitions, seminars and networking events and the theme for the ACS Spring Conference is 'Advanced Materials, Technologies, Systems and Processes'. Xenemetrix will be featuring its cutting edge X-ray analytical instrumentation at booth 1706. Analytical and industrial instrumentation from Xenemetrix range from portable field or at-line instrumentation, benchtop units ranging in performance to floor standing advanced capability laboratory instrumentation. Among the instruments on display at the event will be the Xenemetrix P- Metrix portable analyzer. The P-Metrix Portable ED-XRF analyzer is a compact ED-XRF system that is designed to produce lab quality results in the field or at-line. Also being featured at the convention will be X-Calibur, Xenemetrix's powerful 50kV, 50W direct excitation system that has a selection of Primary Beam Filters / Collimators to enhance performance and for the ultimate in sensitivity and compact size, Xenemetrix will feature its Genius IF, a system that provides monochromatic excitation using the Xenemetrix WAG geometry secondary targets that provides sub ppm detection limits for a wide range of elements - features that push back the frontiers of performance providing a very sensitive analytical tool at a very affordable price point. Bruce Rowlands, Chief Executive Officer stated, 'Our participation of the ACS convention in San Francisco will provide a great opportunity to showcase Xenemetrix's leading edge product line to the broader scientific community. Like Isranalytical, we anticipate that the Xenemetrix product line will be well received.' About Xenemetrix Ltd. About Eurocontrol Technics Group Inc. Eurocontrol is a TSX Venture and OTCQB traded company that specializes in the acquisition, development and commercialization of innovative test and measurement technologies for industry with application technologies focused on the energy security, semiconductor and precision farming sectors based on Xenemetrix's core technological platform of ED-XRF. Eurocontrol has three wholly owned subsidiaries, Xenemetrix Ltd., XwinSys Technology Development Ltd. and Croptimal Ltd. and an agreement with SICPA S.A. for semi-annual earn-out payments of 5% (minimum $9 million over six years) on revenues generated from the oil and gas marking and monitoring field relating to the sale of its former subsidiary Global Fluids International (GFI) S.A. Xenemetrix is a leading designer, manufacturer and marketer of ED-XRF systems, a technology that is the most accurate and economic method for determining the chemical composition of many types of materials, including the analysis of petroleum oils and fuel. Xenemetrix has an exclusive long-term supply, maintenance and support agreement with SICPA/GFI to supply SICPA/GFI with Xenemetrix products and services related to the oil and gas marking and monitoring field. XwinSys has developed a patented, fully automated metrology system for the semiconductor industry that combines 2D and 3D image processing technology with Xenemetrix's ED-XRF technology. Croptimal, is introducing a new mobile ED-XRF spectroscopic material analysis laboratory for the precision agriculture industry that could dramatically change agricultural testing methodology and increase crop yields. title: AJX AgJunction loses $18.21-million (U.S.) in 2016
article: AgJunction Inc (TSX:AJX) Shares Issued 124,534,870 Last Close 3/23/2017 $0.52 Thursday March 23 2017 - News Release Mr. Dave Vaughn reports AGJUNCTION REPORTS FOURTH QUARTER AND FULL YEAR 2016 EARNINGS RESULTS AgJunction Inc. is releasing its financial results for the fourth quarter and full year ended Dec. 31, 2016. On Oct. 15, 2015, AgJunction successfully completed a merger with Novariant Inc., strengthening its position within the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) precision guidance and machine control markets. AgJunction's consolidated fourth quarter and full-year 2016 results are presented as a combined entity. However, the comparative fourth quarter of 2015 includes only partial contribution from Novariant's operations. Fourth quarter 2016 financial summary versus fourth quarter 2015: - Total sales were $8.2-million, compared with $11.6-million. - Gross margin increased to 35.1 per cent, compared with 23.7 per cent. - Net loss was $2.9-million or two cents per share, compared with $9.9-million or nine cents per share. - Adjusted EBITDA (net income before interest and other loss (income), income tax, depreciation, and amortization) was negative $2.4-million, compared with negative $4.5-million. Full-year 2016 financial summary versus full-year 2015: - Total sales were $42.3-million, compared with $39.0-million. - Gross margin increased to 39.1 per cent, compared with 38.0 per cent. - Net loss was $18.2-million or 15 cents per share, compared with $9.1-million or 11 cents per share. - Adjusted EBITDA was negative $4.9-million, compared with negative $2.9-million. Management commentary "Our fourth quarter and full-year results reflect the weakness in the global agriculture industry," said Dave Vaughn, president and chief executive officer of AgJunction. "We are using this slowdown as an opportunity to reconfigure the company to best serve the needs of our global customer base so that we are ready with the right products when the market inevitably recovers. In fact, we have assembled a dedicated team to answer the demand from global platform producers for vehicle-specific, AgJunction-engineered after-market retrofit kits, and this effort is showing early success with several OEM prospects. "Our partners continued to integrate our technology 'behind the scenes' in the fourth quarter. For example, one of our top OEM customers adopted our new terminal hardware and integrated our latest innovative software functionality on an assortment of their automatic steering systems. Adoption of this software functionality allows both our customers and AgJunction to expand into emerging markets. "Looking to 2017, we will continue to focus on delivering products and technology that best suit our clients' needs in both today's market and in the long term. We will also continue to utilize our strong patent portfolio to drive creative new business opportunities as we have done with our recent agreement with Reichhardt GmbH. Given our deep industry experience, innovative product development and strong IP, all supported by our strong balance sheet, we believe we are well positioned to help our customers both today and into the future." Fourth quarter 2016 financial results Total sales in the fourth quarter decreased to $8.2-million, compared with $11.6-million in the fourth quarter of 2015, due to continued softening in the agriculture market. Gross profit in the fourth quarter increased slightly to $2.9-million, compared with $2.8-million in the fourth quarter of 2015. Gross margin increased to 35.1 per cent, compared with 23.7 per cent in the fourth quarter of 2015. The fourth quarter of 2015 included one-time reserves of $700,000 relating to inventory designated for early market removal, as well as $600,000 in additional expenses related to fair value increases of Novariant inventory. Total operating expenses declined 27 per cent to $5.7-million, compared with $7.8-million in the fourth quarter of 2015, due to the rationalization of the company's work force since the Novariant acquisition. As a percentage of sales, operating expenses were 69.3 per cent, compared with 66.6 per cent in the fourth quarter of 2015. Net loss in the fourth quarter of 2016 was $2.9-million or two cents per diluted share, compared with a net loss of $9.9-million or nine cents per diluted share in the fourth quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA in the fourth quarter was negative $2.4-million, compared with negative $4.5-million in the fourth quarter of 2015. Cash and cash equivalents at the end of the fourth quarter totalled $12.9-million, compared with $13.0-million at the end of 2015. The company continues to carry no debt. Working capital was $22.4-million, down slightly from $26.7-million at the end of 2015. Full-year 2016 financial results Total sales in 2016 increased 8 per cent to $42.3-million, compared with $39.0-million in 2015. The increase was primarily driven by the acquisition of Novariant. Gross profit was $16.5-million, compared with $14.8-million in 2015. Gross margin was 39.1 per cent, compared with 38.0 per cent in 2015. (TSX: AJX) ("AgJunction" or the "Company"), a leader in automated steering and machine control technology for precision agriculture, reported financial results for the fourth quarter and full year ended December 31, 2016. ("Novariant"), strengthening its position within the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) precision guidance and machine control markets. title: Winter Tire Market to Surpass $23 Billion by 2021, Says TechSci Research
article: NEW YORK, March 21, 2017 /PRNewswire-iReach/ -- According to recently published TechSci Research report, "Global Winter Tire Market Forecast & Opportunities, 2021", the global market of winter tire is anticipated to cross $23 Billion by 2021. One of the major factors aiding the global winter tire market is favorable government laws. In Quebec (Canada), the use of winter tires is mandatory between December 15 and March 15, and a fine ranging from USD160 to USD250 is levied as a punishment. While, in British Columbia, winter tires are required by law in certain mountainous regions from October 1 to March 31. All these favorable government mandates are aiding global winter tire market. title: CNH Industrial Canada, Ltd. Patent Issued for Method of Using a Particulate Material Delivery System to Pneumatically Dispense Seed Product (USPTO 9585305)
article: 2017 MAR 20 (VerticalNews) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Journal of Engineering -- A patent by the inventors Henry, James W. (Saskatoon, CA); Stuart, Graham D. (Saskatoon, CA); Wolowski, Evan J. B. (Saskatton, CA); Petruic, Matthew G. (Saskatoon, CA), filed on July 17, 2015, was published online on March 7, 2017, according to news reporting originating from Alexandria, Virginia, by VerticalNews correspondents. Patent number 9585305 is assigned to CNH Industrial Canada, Ltd. (Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, CA). The following quote was obtained by the news editors from the background information supplied by the inventors: "Modern large acreage seeding implements pneumatically deliver seed, fertilizer, and/or other product to fields. An example is an air cart and an air drill that are pulled together behind a tractor to deliver product. Different seeding styles can be implemented by using different openers on the air drills. Knife, ribbon band, ribbon band sweep, double-shoot, and disk openers can be used for different seeding styles that can open correspondingly different styles of furrows to receive the seed. The air cart pneumatically conveys seed to the air drill for delivery into the furrow(s). Air carts include one or more storage compartments that hold product(s), each of which has an associated metering box. The metering box divides product(s) from the associated storage compartment(s) into equal sections for delivery of equal product volumes. The equally divided product(s) is entrained in an airflow established by a fan and delivered through manifolds and distribution lines that direct the product from the air cart, to the air drill, and to the field being planted with seed." In addition to the background information obtained for this patent, VerticalNews journalists also obtained the inventors' summary information for this patent: "The present invention is directed to a particulate material delivery system that allows for variable rate sectional control while delivering particulate material to an agricultural field. The system may be incorporated with air carts and air drills, and that includes a metering system having multiple metering units that are independently controllable. This may allow for individual controlling product delivery rates through metering units so as to independently control the delivery rate(s) to each of multiple secondary distribution headers or manifolds, which may allow for sectional control of product delivery from the air drill. "According to one aspect of the present invention, a particulate material delivery system is provided that may include an air cart and a planter that are towable behind a tractor. A metering system of the particulate material delivery system receives a product from the air cart and delivers the product to the planter for distribution to the ground, such as an agricultural field. The metering system may include multiple metering units that receive separate portions of the product from the air cart. Multiple prime movers may drive the multiple metering units. A controller is connected to and individually controls the multiple prime movers such that distribution rates of the multiple metering units can be varied independently of each other. The multiple prime movers may be electric motors. "According to another aspect, each of the multiple metering units may include a metering roller, and a shaft that supports and rotates the metering roller. The electric motors may directly drive ends of the shafts that support the metering roller. "According to another aspect, each of the multiple metering units may include a metering roller having an external gear at an outer circumferential surface thereof. Each electric motor may directly drive the external gear of a respective metering roller. "According to another aspect, each of the multiple metering units may include a metering roller having an internal gear at an inner circumferential surface thereof. Each electric motor ma directly drive the internal gear of a respective metering roller. "According to another aspect, an airflow characteristic of an airflow that entrains the product may be controlled based on a delivery rate of at least one of the multiple metering units for pneumatically conveying product from the multiple metering units toward multiple opener units of the drill. The delivery rate of the product to multiple locations of the agricultural field may be individually controlled by controlling the delivery rate of product through each of the multiple metering units and controlling the airflow characteristic. This may allow for providing a particulate material delivery system that provides delivery consistency and control without requiring singulation-type equipment such as row-unit planters, which may provide a relatively simple and cost-effective air-seeder-type particulate material delivery system with a high amount of delivery accuracy. This may allow for delivery rate variability at secondary headers or manifolds of a single drill which allows for site specific precision farming. This may also allow for relatively more application precision by way of variable rate sectional control of a drill as compared to typical drills that each typically allows for delivery rate variability of only the whole drill. "Other aspects, objects, features, and advantages of the invention will become apparent to those skilled in the art from the following detailed description and accompanying drawings. It should be understood, however, that the detailed description and specific examples, while indicating preferred embodiments of the present invention, are given by way of illustration and not of limitation. Many changes and modifications may be made within the scope of the present invention without departing from the spirit thereof and the invention includes all such modifications." title: AJX AgJunction to allow GNSS to sell to agricultural market
article: AgJunction Inc (TSX:AJX) Shares Issued 124,534,870 Last Close 3/17/2017 $0.51 Monday March 20 2017 - News Release Mr. Farlin Halsey reports AGJUNCTION SIGNS NEW STRATEGIC AGREEMENT WITH HEMISPHERE GNSS AgJunction Inc. has entered a new strategic agreement with Hemisphere GNSS Inc., a world-class provider of global navigation satellite systems (GNSS) technology. For an undisclosed, one-time payment and a new long-term supply agreement, AgJunction has agreed to release Hemisphere from a licence restriction that prevented it from selling its GNSS products directly into the global agricultural market. Supply and market restriction agreements previously created between AgJunction and Hemisphere ended in 2016 while the market restriction agreements continued indefinitely. The agreement is expected to provide customers a more direct relationship with their GNSS supplier, creating better efficiencies for original equipment manufacturers, value-added resellers and growers alike. This agreement is also consistent with AgJunction's desire to provide its steering customers the ability to choose among several possible GNSS options. Regarding the agreement, Dave Vaughn, chief executive officer of AgJunction, said: "AgJunction is pleased with the signing of this agreement as it will ensure our customers, who have chosen Hemisphere's GNSS receivers and antenna technology, direct access and an uninterrupted supply. As a leader in the precision steering machine control business, it is incumbent upon us to provide the GNSS solution our customers prefer and this agreement does just that." This agreement does not affect AgJunction's exclusive right to sell certain steering and machine control technology covered by the company's extensive IP portfolio into the agriculture market. Hemisphere's president and CEO, Farlin Halsey, stated: "Hemisphere is excited to work more directly with our OEM agriculture partners. This new supply agreement will forge a deeper relationship, providing faster response to sales and support requests, and increased customer feedback, resulting in stronger innovation and solutions." Mr. Halsey added, "We would also like to thank AgJunction and look forward to both companies' future success." Specific terms of the transaction were not disclosed. About AgJunction Inc. AgJunction provides innovative hardware and software applications for precision agriculture worldwide. The company holds more than 140 patents and markets its products and services under leading brand names including Novariant, Outback Guidance and Satloc. AgJunction is headquartered in Hiawatha, Kan., with executive offices in Fremont, Calif., and facilities in Scottsdale, Ariz., Winnipeg, Man., and Brisbane, Queensland, Australia. We seek Safe Harbor.

title: Syngenta 2016: North America.
article: North America comprises Canada and the US. It generates about 25% of Syngenta's revenue. Its growers - among the most competitive and productive in the world - are typically early adopters of new technologies, from crop and seed protection to soil conservation and digital farming. The region has about 10% of the global planted area, but half the world's genetically modified seed cultivation. The company reported sales of $3202 M in North America in 2016. It has 4176 employees in the region. Excluding the impact of non-recurring royalty income in 2015, sales were just 2% lower. The company maintained Crop Protection sales, despite the dry weather in the West and South, which reduced demand for fungicides. Sales growth was led by strong new product introductions including ACURON corn herbicide and a range of fungicides applying its SOLATENOL technology. Syngenta annual review 2016

title: Press Release: Innovative New Offerings from AgJunction Strategic Partners Showcased at 2017 SIMA Show
article: Innovative New Offerings from AgJunction Strategic Partners Showcased at 2017 SIMA Show PR Newswire HIAWATHA, KS, March 14, 2017 HIAWATHA, KS, March 14, 2017 /PRNewswire/ - AgJunction, Inc. (TSX:AJX), a leading provider of innovative hardware and software solutions for precision agriculture, had several products from their suite of solutions showcased by several strategic partners at the 2017 SIMA show in Paris, which ran from February 26(th) to March 2(nd) . CLAAS, one of the world's leading suppliers of agricultural engineering equipment, demonstrated their new TURN IN feature, an extension to their current steering system that automatically guides the driver into the optimum track on turning while allowing for extremely fast maneuvering at the headland, thus reducing driver workload. This innovation by CLAAS software garnered them a special mention award at the SIMA show. Learn more here. Kverneland Group, a subsidiary of Kubota Tractor, showcased their new IsoMatch AutoDrive E, an automatic steering solution for the aftermarket. While the steering is handled automatically, the farmer is able to control and monitor their work in a more relaxed way and can focus 100% of their attention to the result in the field. More information can be found here. Dave Vaughn, CEO of AgJunction said: "AgJunction is pleased to see our customer's release innovative new solutions that provide differentiation in a crowded field of competitors. Our expansive suite of products and services allows our customers to select the combination of technologies that best suits their needs." title: Scientists study how to make poorer soils perform better; Canada is working with the G20 on research projects
article: As Canada steadily loses top quality farmland to urban sprawl, Agriculture Canada scientists are studying ways to make poorer soils perform better in cooperation with foreign researchers. Knowing the global population will reach 9.5 billion in 2050, "we're looking at how to maximize our productivity on these less productive lands and doing so in a manner that is not harmful to the environment," Brian Gray, assistant deputy minister for science and technology told the Senate agriculture committee. Increasing productivity of all land is one of four strategic objectives of the department's researchers. The work is being conducted in concert with the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the chief scientists of the agriculture departments of the G20 countries. "We're still early days, because I think we've had four years, but we're identifying the biggest threats and opportunities facing the G20 countries in agriculture," he said. "We look not so much at pooling money and putting it in one basket but collaborating on research where we're twinning funding. We're already working on this. We want to align our scientists with their scientists, whether in government or academia." A common theme in the committee's study of farmland ownership is the loss of the Class 1, 2 and 3 soils to urbanization and the addition of more Class 5 and 6 soils to the faming base. Allan Howard, Manager of the Agroclimate, Geomatics and Earth Observation Division, said the department's land use and soils data "indicates that farmland is being lost to urban expansion in Canada every year, with much of this occurring in Ontario, Quebec, Prince Edward Island and British Columbia, where the majority of Canada's best farmland is found." Meanwhile land coming into agriculture tends to be Class 4 and 5. The department is looking at whether climate change is making some land of use to agriculture, he said. Research will be conducted on what the land across the country might be like by mid-century. "There is certainly land coming into production that was not farmed 20 or 30 years." One example is grapes for wine production. "There are a lot of wineries in the Okanagan, and they are looking to find areas where they can expand. "The questions we have to ask are how much land is going to go from marginal and improved to be class 1, 2 or 3," he said. "How much of the unsuitable land will become marginal land? How much of our prime land is going to lose productivity as a result of climate change? It may not be strictly because of things like drought. It could be extreme heat stress, pests or a number of things; so there are a number of questions we need to be aware of and still need to answer. I would say we're at the very early stages." Research scientist Ted Huffman said, monitoring land-use changes isdifficultbecauseithappensat it at "isolated locations here and there across the country." New information systems show about 3,000 hectares of farmland per year being urbanized between 1990 and 2010, almost half of it in Ontario. At the same time, about 2,000 hectares of forest is converted to agricultural use across the country each year. "The major contributor there is Alberta, 800 to about 900 hectares per year, followed by Quebec at about 400 hectares per year, Saskatchewan, 500 hectares per year," he said. Natural Resources Canada is developing a Federal Geospatial Platform to use satellite data on alllandusesinCanada land Canada, he said. This could assist the federal and provincial governments in establishing a standard land use policies and designations. Gray said the department is working to keep pace with new farming technology advances, such as precision farming. They "are creating an increased demand for evidence based decision making at finer and finer scales, down to subfield levels beyond what is possible from the current soils database. "In order to address this need, we have initiated discussions with the provinces, universities and private sectors about a common integrated approach to increase the resolution of our soils data, he said. His department "is currently conducting research to develop nationally consistent farm-field level soil data using a new approach called predictive soil mapping." It should produce more detailed soil maps at significantly reduced costs over the traditional field survey based approach. Soil data only informs about the suitability of land for cropping purposes, not what is currently happening on the land base.

title: DVR Deveron to provide drone-based data to Thompsons
article: Deveron UAS Corp (TSX:DVR) Shares Issued 17,115,506 Last Close 3/7/2017 $0.49 Tuesday March 07 2017 - News Release Mr. David MacMillan reports DEVERON SIGNS MULTI-YEAR CONTRACT TO PROVIDE DRONE BASED DATA SOLUTIONS Deveron UAS Corp. has made a multiyear commitment to working with Thompsons Ltd. to provide leading-edge remote sensing data solutions to its growers. The contract is expected to run through 2018. Thompsons Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of U.S.-based Lansing Trade Group LLC and the Andersons Inc., is a major agricultural retailer that has been in business since 1924. Its people and innovation have contributed to its success with a core focus of providing its growers with customized, advanced agronomy solutions. Drone data are being incorporated into the revolutionary business of precision agriculture, which is a system that places the right product, at the right time, in the right place according to the unique variability on a farm. The focus of Thompsons's advanced agronomy product is to help growers achieve more profit per acre. Drone data and on-demand imagery are key ingredients in this process that can help drive accurate field scouting, near-real-time crop maps, management zone creation for variable rate input prescriptions and detailed yield maps for growers. "We are excited to be partnering with Deveron UAS to help us continue to more precisely document the variability that every field has," commented Jevin Vyn, agronomy solutions specialist at Thompsons Ltd. "Deveron has proven to be a leader in the imagery market, and we believe that through our partnership we will be able to bring our customers new innovations in this space. As well, we will be able to utilize drone data on many of our customers' acres to help them increase profitability on their farm." David MacMillan, president and chief executive officer, Deveron UAS, commented, "Our multiyear deal with a prestigious firm like Thompsons Ltd. is further evidence that Deveron continues to dominate and lead innovation in drone-data-related precision agriculture." About Deveron UAS Corp. Deveron is an enterprise drone data services company focused on agriculture, offering the opportunity to increase yields and reduce costs using sophisticated unmanned aerial systems (UAS or drones), sensors, software and analytics. Deveron's drone data service network allows enterprise level customers to obtain on-demand, actionable data without exposure to technology and capital risks. The company is focused on building a standardized constellation of drones and sensors to provide data in North America. We seek Safe Harbor.

title: Experimental farm reopens to strengthen Canadian crops against climate change
article: An experimental farm in Quebec is scheduled to reopen this spring to expand water and soil research, and also strengthen the agriculture sector's ability to adapt to climate change. The Canadian government announced in December that the Frelighsburg Experimental Farm will reopen in 2017 to study new techniques in topics like biovigilance, precision farming and crop management. Researchers will also collect information on fruit varieties that are able to withstand extreme temperature fluctuations, to increase resiliency of Canadian crops to climate change. "Science is a powerful tool for environmental action on Canadian farms," said Lawrence MacAulay, Canada's minister of agriculture, when the experimental farm's reopening was announced. "This research in Frelighsburg will help our farmers increase production to feed a growing population, while protecting our environment - a win for farmers and Canadians." Frelighsburg was one of several experimental farms closed by the Conservative government in 2012. ''Innovative agricultural research here will help ... producers get the tools they need to ensure their prosperity and sustainability,'' said Pierre Paradis, Quebec's minister of agriculture, fisheries and food, in the reopening announcement. The farm is located about 80 kilometres southeast of Montreal and is a satellite site of the Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu Research and Development Centre.

article: Based on field-centric data, Corn Manager is the most comprehensive toolset today for daily, dynamic decision-support  "Efficient, fast, and exceedingly easy to use, Corn Manager represents a major breakthrough for the industry as it transitions from precision agriculture to decision agriculture," said Dr. Solomon Folle, Senior Cropping System Modeller at Farmers Edge. title: Farmers Edge Unveils Next-Gen FarmCommand(TM), Shifting Industry from Precision to Decision Agriculture
article: The only independent, integrated farm management platform on the market, FarmCommand delivers what growers need most: swift, accurate, in-field decision support  COMMODITY CLASSIC -- Farmers Edge(TM), a global leader in decision agriculture, today launched the next generation of its award-winning farm management platform, FarmCommand(TM). Based on two years of feedback from its global network of growers, the new fully-integrated platform provides growers with easy access to crop, weather, equipment, soil, and other agronomic data all in one place. This announcement comes as Farmers Edge also introduces Corn Manager(TM) to growers at this year's Commodity Classic in San Antonio, Texas. Corn Manager -- the first corn management system that combines effective nitrogen management, high-frequency satellite imagery, and accurate crop staging into one easy-to-use tool -- will also be available as an optional feature within FarmCommand. Smarter, Faster, Stronger: FarmCommand Advances Data-Driven Ag into New Era While growers are quickly adapting to the new era of decision agriculture, existing technologies have largely forced them to use multiple systems to manage and utilize data, leaving them ill-equipped to capitalize on the promises of big data on the farm. Now, for the first time in the industry, growers will be able to access all data in one, easy-to-use platform that offers a wide array of information, features and services, including:  "The most important thing for our operations is having access to technologies that are easy to use and don't require us to bring new equipment to the farm," said Matt Helmke, a Farmers Edge grower from Nebraska. "Farmers Edge offers us a complete farm management tool that we can integrate into our existing gear. More than that, they also offer us in-field advisors to further ensure we can make the best possible decisions on the farm." From Health to Harvest to Profit, FarmCommand Manages It All Designed to manage multiple data streams in a single system, FarmCommand includes a host of features in its powerful Map Manager, which seamlessly analyzes and displays data, regardless of the source. Within the system, growers have access to: Crop Health Maps that monitor and track the in-season health of crops; Harvest Maps that provide accurate yield data to identify opportunities and confidently evaluate decision results; Profit Maps that integrate application prescriptions, harvest data, commodity costs, product costs, and check strip data to evaluate ROI on a zone-by-zone basis; and many more value-added features. FarmCommand easily transforms the complexities of big data intelligence into in-field decisions. "At Eastern Colorado Seeds, we're focused on bringing our growers technologies that ensure the most productive farming possible, while also promoting local, economic growth," said Clay Smith, CEO of Eastern Colorado Seeds. "FarmCommand from Farmers Edge fits the needs of our customers and ensures that they can leverage critical crop health and variability data, field-centric weather, soil insights, and a wide swath of additional farm and field data to help drive decisions that maximize profitability without forcing them to adopt new, expensive farm equipment in the process." 9.2M Acres and Counting: Farmers Edge Continues as Leading Innovator in Agriculture Since 2005, Farmers Edge has been at the forefront of bringing grower-centric technologies to producers throughout the largest and most vital agriculture markets. Serving 9.2 million paid product acres around the globe, including regions like the U.S. Midwest, Canada, Brazil, Russia, and Australia, Farmers Edge has cemented its position as one of the industry's top innovators, introducing a wide variety of data-driven technologies and solutions, including:  "At a time when growers are challenged by slumping commodity prices and a shortage of farm labor, we're more focused than ever on ensuring growers are well-equipped with tools that support decision-making on the farm," said Wade Barnes, President and CEO of Farmers Edge. "Like our previous solutions and technologies, the new FarmCommand is based on years of R&D and was designed to help producers thrive in this new age of decision-centric farming." About Farmers Edge  Caroline Venza farmersedge@missionc2.com  (END)

title: Agrium Inc at Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Agriculture and Chemicals Conference - Final
article: Presentation STEVE BYRNE , ANALYST, BANK OF AMERICA MERRILL LYNCH: (Starts Abruptly) Chemicals for BoA Merrill. And it's a pleasure to introduce Agrium here as our last presentation for the afternoon. I won't mention it to Chuck that he is the last in line before the cocktail hour, but so I won't mention that, Chuck. But it's a pleasure to have Chuck Magro here, Chuck has been with Agrium for eight years, he's had a variety of roles, sales, corporate developments, operations, he's had the CEO role for the last few years. He previously had a very successful career at NOVA Chemicals , so it's a pleasure to have you here, Chuck and we'll pass it over to you. CHUCK MAGRO, CEO, AGRIUM, INC.: Thanks, Steve. Hi, everyone. So if I'm the last one before alcohol, I'll be fairly quick here. I was thinking maybe you should get a drink first, because that would be more entertaining, but I'm not sure you'll pay attention. So it's great to be here. What I thought I'd do today is just take a couple of minutes, probably 15 minutes or so, talk about Agrium 's business, I'll give you an update on the current Ag market, how we see the spring season and then wrap up with just our priorities for 2017 and talk a little bit about the merger with PotashCorp . There is our forward-looking statement. Let's start with an overview of our Company. So most of you know Agrium , I hope. We're an agricultural inputs company. We are integrated, we go right from production of fertilizer right through to the retail distribution to the farm gate. We are fairly unique in that manner. We have a diversified Ag portfolio and we are either producing and/or selling all the major fertilizers, crop chemistry and seed and we're one of the largest Precision Ag players out there today. So we basically provide all the products and services that a grower needs to maximize their yield. This slide gives you a quick snapshot of our North American footprint, it's pretty important because, it's about 80% of our revenue and earnings. And you can see that there is a combination of our production businesses with our retail distribution assets. And this picture really is what makes Agrium unique in the Ag inputs space. The retail business is the Premier Ag retail business literally in the world. We have operations in Canada, the US, Australia and South America, about 1,500 facilities operating in seven countries. We purchase about 10 million tons of fertilizer, $4.5 billion of crop chemistry, $1.5 billion of seed and have our own Proprietary Chemicals and Specialty Nutrition product, we call them Loveland Products. The wholesale production business, 11 million tons of NP&K, very high quality asset, and we benefit from strong global competitive advantages across most of these product line, especially in Western Canada where we have quite a natural gas advantage. The highly complementary nature of our production and distribution businesses is what sets us apart. This integration allows us to really deliver resilient earnings and strong free cash flow. It's also allowed us to have a leading and sustainable dividend across the cycle, even in these market conditions. I'll switch gears now, talk a little bit about the market and what we're seeing. In the US, we had a relatively normal harvest with very strong crop yields once again, really three years in a row above trend yields. We also saw a solid nutrient removal as a result of that in the United States and somewhat in Canada. And for the fall application in the US, we also saw very good application rates for P&K. In Western Canada, it was slightly a different story. We had a delayed harvest activities because of the early snowfall, and so we really didn't get a lot of ammonia down in the fall in Western Canada. And we're seeing that now with a very strong demand outlook for Western Canada and in our order book, both in wholesale and in retail. When I look at the Ag market, overall, I'd still say that the fundamentals are still challenging, but there are some reasons to be cautiously optimistic. Crop prices, for example are stable and slightly higher than last year, in fact. And our business in retail, we saw very strong prepay across North America. And prepay, we use as a bit of a barometer to indicate future farmer spending intentions with us and that was actually up year-over-year, which is really good news. And then as you can see in this chart here, farmer cash margins are actually expected to improve slightly this year, which would be the first time actually in three years, which we find that to be a very good time. Crop prices remain very affordable, you can see in this chart, which is fertilizer prices as a percentage of revenue for major crops like corn are well below the five-year average. In fact, on this basis, nutrients are the most affordable they've been since 2010, which we think bodes well for fertilizer demand this spring. Moving to fertilizer prices, and nitrogen, urea prices have improved after falling to unsustainably low levels. Chinese urea production costs increased last year and we saw exports drop off significantly and that's what led to the recent rally we've seen in benchmark nitrogen prices. Now once the spring is complete, we do see the potential for seasonal weakness in nitrogen as well as probably some dislocation in some premium as the North American market has to absorb some of the new capacity coming online, most likely in the second half of the year. However, longer term, we are very constructive on nitrogen as the global supply demand we believe will continue to tighten in 2018, 2019. In potash, we're seeing firm demand for supply for potash right around the world in terms of the first half of the year and it's been quite strong actually since the second half of the year. We expect demand globally to grow 5% up from the 59 million tons we saw last year. So the market is continuing to grow, which is very, very helpful. And for this -- after the spring season, really it's going to depend on a few things, the timing and the rate at which the new capacity comes online, the timing of new contracts with our international buyers and of course, the global growth rate, will it continue. So those are some of the key factors that will determine how long the strength in potash will continue. I'll talk now a little bit more about our operations. I'll start with wholesale, so this is a world-class production business, I've mentioned the 11 million tons of capacity, both low cost and have really attractive end market competitive advantages. And I think an important thing to note is after many years of capacity expansion and capital spending, now our capital program and wholesale is just -- it's almost complete, it will be complete actually at the end of this first quarter. And in recent years, we've added now 600,000 tons of nitrogen at our Borger, Texas plant and then 1 million tons of potash capacity at Vanscoy. Included in the wholesale 11 million tons is about 5 million tons of nitrogen in North America. It's a very high margin nitrogen business, it's backstopped by low cost natural gas, especially in western Canada where we have the ACOG gas advantage. And this chart actually shows the cash cost of production for urea compared to some of the high cost producers. The market today is fitting basically at the high cost production cost curve and you can see on the far left there that our gas position at $2 an MMBtu is very, very attractive. And that is a substantial cost advantage even compared to our North American NYMEX peers. So I think that it really demonstrates how strong our nitrogen business is from a cost perspective, especially in Western Canada. And when you take that cost advantage and then you look at the end-market pricing advantage that we have and especially, if you consider that four out of our five plants are located in Western Canada, you can see there's a healthy uplift to pricing because of our logistical advantage in having our production up in Western Canada. In fact in Q4, we had the highest margins among our North American peers by a very wide margin. So the combination of low cost gas, end market logistics advantage makes our nitrogen business as the strong cash generator. In potash, as I've mentioned, we've completed the 1 million ton capacity expansion, which brings Vanscoy's total capacity to 3 million tons. This will lower our cash cost of production to below $70 a ton, ensuring that these assets are highly competitive globally and among the highest quality in the world. And we expect to generate meaningful earnings and cash flow from the investments going forward. On to retail. As I mentioned, really an unparalleled Ag retail business. You can see that the business is very, very large, over $12 billion in revenue, $2.8 billion in gross profit with a strong exposure to a very diversified crops as well as you can see on the chart, we've grown the business quite steadily through a combination of both acquisition and organic growth. And one of the key growth levers that we have is really our proprietary products business. And this is a great business for us because it has very high margins compared to the margins we get by buying and reselling third-party products. Our proprietary products portfolio continues to grow and add significant value to the bottom line. This includes our Loveland Crop Protection and Specialty Nutritional products, as well as our proprietary seed brand. We now have over 250 brands in the portfolio, so it has grown quite a bit. And as we made solid progress growing the brands in 2016, the proprietary products actually have increase to 15% of our overall retail sales. A little bit now on how we've been managing the downturn in the commodity cycle and controlling our controllables. In wholesale, we've continued to drive out cost and increased our reliability across the business. Our cash cost of production in 2016 for both urea and potash were well below our public targets that we laid out last year. So we've made just great progress in the last two years. Last year in 2016, we actually set record production for both nitrogen and our potash businesses, and if you take on top of that we also removed $60 million of fixed costs out of our wholesale business in a relatively short period of time. In retail, we've also worked on cutting costs, optimizing our network and improving our profitability. We've made excellent progress in optimizing the network in 2016, closing over 60 facilities. Collectively, these changes have allowed us to take out another $70 million of fixed cost out of the retail business. And as a result, our cash operating coverage ratio improved by 1% to 61% and our EBITDA margin now reached an impressive 9.3%. We also set a record EBITDA margin for our United States retail business at 10.4%. So we've made really good progress towards our 2020 stated target. In fact growing retail remains a strategic priority for us and we have multiple pathways underway right now to continue to grow. Of course, we've talked about growing by M&A, we call this our tuck-in program, but we are also building Greenfield locations now in some select high-value markets. We're also focused on organic growth by optimizing the network further and by achieving even deeper penetration of our proprietary products. And finally, we just introduced a new business, the Agrium Financial Services business, which will be another catalyst for growth in the retail portfolio. As I mentioned, our tuck-in program, it's a big part of our growth strategy. We've -- since 2010, we've been a very active consolidator, rolling up the Ag retail space, especially in Canada and the United States and we had an exceptional year last year where we had a record 76 acquisitions, acquiring about $500 million of annual revenue. And these acquisitions typically are highly accretive and a significant source of value creation. And looking ahead, our pipeline remains very solid for 2017. Everything we do at Agrium is to drive shareholder value. Specifically, we are focused on building an integrated platform that delivers stable and free cash flow. In recent years, we've invested in low-cost, high-quality capacity in our wholesale business as well as we've allocated significant capital to grow our retail business and consolidate the space to drive the integration and stability of the overall portfolio. We've also spent a significant amount of time and energy working on our base business and hopefully I've shown some of those results today. And now that the CapEx program is behind us, if you look and you take a step back at our business, we have this uniquely integrated Ag business that can maintain a very strong balance sheet, pursue profitable growth and be a leader in returning capital to shareholders. I think it's a great story and will only be enhanced with the PotashCorp merger. When I look at the merger, this is truly a unique, and I think transformational opportunity for Agrium , the PotashCorp and for both sets of shareholder. When you look at the combination of the two companies, the strategic fit is very strong and the industrial logic, very, very sound. We will create the world's largest integrated crop inputs provider, we will have a very strong balance sheet with the financial strength to continue to grow the Company and still a lot of ability to return capital to shareholders. Now, we've committed to $500 million of annual operating synergies that are well within our control, this represents very significant value creation with no help from the market. So when I step back and I look at the big picture, this is the right deal at the right time with the right partner. In terms of a quick update, we obviously have received a very strong endorsement from both sets of shareholders. With our vote in November, our integration planning with PotashCorp is well underway and I'm very pleased with the progress. We have received regulatory clearance from Brazil and Russia, we still expect to close the transaction mid-year in 2017. So with that, I'll turn it over to either Steve or you, for some questions. Questions and Answers STEVE BYRNE : Anybody have questions for Chuck? We have one up here. Let me just open it up while waiting on this one, Chuck. Your retail business in the US, I think have some market share, maybe shy of 20% or close to 20%, where would you like that to be in another 10 years? CHUCK MAGRO: That's right. Steve, so it's 19% so the market share in the US. And if you look at the jurisdictions that the retail business is operating under the US is our most profitable, it's our largest business, but it has the lowest market share. In fact, Western Canada, the market share would be close to 30% and similar numbers in Australia and in Argentina. So we'd like to continue to grow the US retail business. We think sort of a mid-term target would be in that 25% range to get to up say, from 19% to 25%. We think we can do that through the programs that we have underway right now. And if we were able to do that, I think we would create just a tremendous amount of value. We continue to see opportunities right now in the pipeline that are very, very attractive. Last year we -- I mentioned the record, but we also bought, two of those acquisitions had 16 to 20 facilities in them. So they're more mid-size acquisitions, and we're starting to see more and more of those become available here in the US. STEVE BYRNE : Is there a size where the value proposition starts to erode in terms of either your private label positioning or density, is there a point where it doesn't make sense to go much further? CHUCK MAGRO: I think one day we will reach that limit, but certainly in the other jurisdictions, we're sort of in that 30% range and we haven't come across any deep concerns there. The United States, we talk about it as one market, but really in regions we will have market share that's slightly higher than that and some we'll be quite well under-penetrated. So we use that as a broad kind of barometer to get across the US, but there's some areas that are in the Corn Belt, in real corn country that we're actually underrepresented, which we would like to grow certain areas more readily. But I don't think we have the limitations that you've described, I don't think we're anywhere near that. So I'd say we have a lot of freedom to get to those kind of market shares certainly in the next period of time. UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Chuck, doubtless you read the recent Wall Street Journal article about the disintermediation of these products. Can you just speak about that threat and I'm guessing that you believe for a variety of reasons the -- a modest threat that you will manage just fine, but can you point to the evidence at hand for the sustainability of your bricks and mortar retail model? CHUCK MAGRO: Yes, it's a great question and we saw the article, we know the parties involved, they're not foreign to us at all, we've had some discussion, we have a relationship with them. Ultimately, the Agrium retail model or in general, the retail model has to create value for the grower. And we believe we do that not only by providing commodities to the farm gate, which is important and the distribution of physical commodities will need to happen no matter how they buy them. So there's always going to be an element of value creation by getting fertilizer, seed and chemistry to the farm gate. But our business is much more than that today. Our business really has to deal with having -- today, we have about 3,000 agronomists working in the fields every day as independent crop advisor, helping growers sort through all the decisions that they need to make to maximize yield. And we don't think that that relationship and that structure is going to change at all. Now, there is a place for digital agriculture and for e-commerce, but we believe that that would be supplemented in any form by having independent advice for the growers to help them maximize crop production. So we don't see it as a threat necessarily, it's another way, I think for growers to get information, which we think and believe it's healthy for growers. But I believe that the model that we have, where we move a lot of bulk commodities to the farm gate (inaudible) we're able to give them every advice, service and actually do a lot of the application with our own equipment, our own fleet of trucks and spreading equipment, I think there is real value for growers by having that kind of service offering for them. So to be determined, we're watching it closely, but certainly, we think that our model is well and healthy. UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Just continuing down that line of thinking, this Precision Ag program you have, you keep bolting on more modules onto this special on package, would you say the value proposition to you, to Agrium is that it drives revenue because of the services that it generates, whether it's variable rate application or soil sampling or whatever, where do you think it drives customer loyalty? CHUCK MAGRO: Yes, I think answer is both. So what we're finding with the Precision Ag platform is it's sort of the mechanism to do -- to have the relationship. Of course, once you have four years, five years of yield and kind of fertilizer and crop chemistry data in the system, it's more sticky, growers won't want to switch once they have all that commitment that they've made on one platform. So there is an element of loyalty and retention. The average age of the farmer is 58 in the United States, so the younger farmer likes to have that technology on their mobile device. They can communicate with us through the system and they can get help from a crop consultant when they need it. It's also allowing us to have fewer crop consultants and handle larger farms and more farms because a lot of the communication and information and analytics are actually in the Precision Ag software. So that's I think a wave of the future. I think ultimately you will not be an Ag retailer without a platform like this. That's probably some of the reason why we're seeing an acceleration in some of the acquisitions on, some of the smaller Ag retailers as they don't have $10 million or $20 million or $50 million to develop their own platform. And the way the market is going is it's going to be certainly a cost of doing business and a cost of entry for Ag retailers. And I think that part of the value proposition that we offer, I think is a great (inaudible) to this notion of just having price transparency and an e-commerce platform. Our e-commerce platform is really the Precision Ag software backstopped by our agronomy. STEVE BYRNE : You showed that map where your footprint is in the retail and you talked about bolting on x number of new retail facilities. Drilling down into their retail business, do you think that you have more opportunity to grow private label chemistry or seeds and you need some acquisitions to be able to do that? CHUCK MAGRO: Our proprietary product is one of the reasons why we set a record of EBITDA in 2016 in the US and had such a strong margin performance across the Company. We think we have invested over $100 million over the last five years in buying or getting access to proprietary technology. And we would continue to look for other acquisitions and investments and even commercial relationships that keep bolstering up our portfolio, because we think that it's a real important part of our growth strategy in trying to optimize the overall network. I don't think you'll ever see us and we think that I guess Steve, to answer your question directly, we can increase the percentage of our current shelves with our proprietary products. But it is a balancing act, because we get incentives from the third-party providers to grow their market share and sell their products. So we're constantly and we have a team of people with sophisticated analytics balancing what we need to sell to maximize our earnings. So the end game isn't just to drive our proprietary product sales for the sake of doing that, it's maximizing our earnings. And right now, last year we got -- we were able to grow our proprietary products percentage, but we also hit the right target for our third-party providers and that's why when you look at our margins for overall, they were up was a combination of our rebate and our proprietary portfolio and that's the balancing act that we're constantly working through. STEVE BYRNE : Your private label seed business is primarily corn and beans, would you be interested in expanding that into other crops if any forced divestitures of seed brands were available? CHUCK MAGRO: Well, right now, we have our own genetics for cotton, for canola and for rice. And then our private label, we do license trades from the majors and we brand them under the Dyna-Gro brand and you're right, it's primarily for corn and for beans. We would be interested in expanding both of those. So it's really a current consolidation wave that's underway. If there is some genetics that came available that are not mainstream, broad acre heavy R&D, where retail had a large market share, so rice is the perfect example. We acquired the genetics for rice, but we have a really high market share of rice acres in the southern part of the US and there's not a lot of R&D left to do, that made an awful lot of sense for us. So on the fringes, we would absolutely do that all day long. If there is more technology or R&D that's required, we would have no interest in that. We're not an R&D company, we're a company that wants to buy these products and services that can differentiate ourselves, but take them directly to market through our channel. And so we'll look at everything that comes available, but we're going to be highly selective, because it has to fit with our strategy, we have no desire to get into heavy investment cost for research and development or even to maintain our technology portfolio, that's not our business. STEVE BYRNE : And would that comment also hold in chemistry? CHUCK MAGRO: Yes, chemistry, so the Loveland Products chemistry, primarily majority of it is really products that are off patent and we've specialized them, we've added some things that are unique to them. But we don't do a tremendous -- we do some, but I'd call it product development, not R&D. So products that are commercially viable today that would fit into that portfolio, we would absolutely be interested. But again, we don't want to go beyond bringing those products to market in terms of having to maintain technology portfolio. So on a chemistry decision, we would look at, are they market ready, do they fit with our existing products, and can we get some synergy by moving a larger percentage of them through our channel. STEVE BYRNE : But versus having a supply agreement with a producer for a particular molecule and then you have the ability to have own private label brand, would you want to have the intellectual property for a molecule to yourself? CHUCK MAGRO: Not necessarily. So the way we think about it, Steve is that we service the grower -- all kinds of the different growers. Some growers want the brand, they want the technology from a third-party. Typically, we're quite comfortable having to buy and resell relationship with that product. Then there's a proprietary product that's not quite a generic, but there is a specialty product, a formulated product of some type, that we would have interested in. And then the generics, if we have a cost position we would take that, but many times we don't. And so we bring in third-party through that as well. And so we think our sweet spot is just in the formulated off-patent areas. Having our own technology will require further investments to maintain the leadership position in that technology and that's not what we want to spend our dollars on. STEVE BYRNE : Part of the rationale with the merger with PotashCorp is to take some of that wholesale potash capacity and push it through your own retail channel. You sell more potash through retail than you produce on wholesale. Was it an option to do that with the tons coming out of the legacy [mine] as an alternative? CHUCK MAGRO: Yes. Actually the driving factor for the Agrium PotashCorp merger has to do with integration of nitrogen and phosphate. Vanscoy itself can service our retail potash needs. So there is very little synergy related to having more capacity from a potash perspective for our retail channel. The value creation will be in saving logistics and distribution cost, streamlining the entire supply chain, which is very large and reducing the overall cost from NP&K right through to the farm gate. So there is very little actual value from having more potash capacity from an integration perspective, but more from nitrogen and phosphate. STEVE BYRNE : And on the phosphate side, is that longer term opportunity in Redwater viable, have you got some alternatives source of rock? CHUCK MAGRO: Talking about from the merger perspective? STEVE BYRNE : Yes. CHUCK MAGRO: Yes. So about $80 million out of the $500 million of synergies is going to come from phosphate. Today most of you know, we buy imported rock from Morocco and then we bring it into Western Canada and we relay to Redwater. So the synergy has to do with using PotashCorp 's rock and asset capability in Florida and North Carolina, exiting our contracts with Morocco and getting backward integrated with Phosrock again and bringing that up to Redwater and saving the price really that we were paying for the Moroccan rock. And we were -- before we bought the Moroccan rock, we were actually integrated Agrium , we used a rock source out of Kapuskasing, Ontario. We did rail it 3,000 kilometers and when we lost the economic viability of that mine, we have to go to a third-party, we lost about $70 a ton and we believe we'll regain that by integrating with the PotashCorp asset. STEVE BYRNE : And on the nitrogen side of the house, is that longer term advantage that you have up in Alberta, is that sustainable longer term and where is the synergy on the nitrogen side? CHUCK MAGRO: The synergy is for the deal on nitrogen are not in Western Canada, they're in the southern part of the US. So right now, PotashCorp produces nitrogen and there's a couple levels of synergies, right? We have some railcars that literally pass each other in the night and now we'll be able to service our retail customers by keeping tons closer to home and saving expensive distribution costs, because now will have more production in the southeast of the US and so we'll be able to prevent some logistics costs. The other driving factor is, PotashCorp uses the industrial nitrogen markets quite a bit and we'll be able to move some of that nitrogen into our retail channel on an Ag basis and keep those tons closer to home, saving logistics cost that way as well. So that's the exciting part for the deal is really optimizing the North American supply chain that we have, both of them are huge, I'll give you just a couple more data point. So the warehouses, we have a combined, almost 400 warehouses, some of them are literally across the street from one another and we'll be able to take out a percentage of those and optimize our distribution points. And I think that there is the lot of value creation through the supply chain even that way. Our rail fleet combine 15,000 railcars and we both have surplus railcars for redundancies and we'll be able to trim the rail fleet reducing costs as well. So it's almost endless when you look at putting these two supply chains together and how we can squeeze out the efficiencies. And since we announced the deal, we've been working on this, now for another two months or three months and I'd say that I'm actually more encouraged about the $500 million annual synergy target than I was even in November. UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Your calculations on margin per acre on major row crops looks like you had a higher margin in corn an bean, which I think is maybe a reversal from only a couple of months ago. Has your outlook for acreage shifts also changed for this upcoming planting season? CHUCK MAGRO: Yes, that's great, Jim. We still think corn will be in the 90 million acres to 92 million acres. We're getting more optimistic that maybe it's closer to the 92 million acres. It's going to depend, if we have a slightly early spring, which who knows if that will actually happen, then you could see even more corn acres come into the play, because if they have more time typically, they'll plant corn. But right now, I think our best view of the markets are 90 million acres to 92 million acres. I think what we're seeing though is, there's strong optimism for the first half of the year at the farm level. Margins are, I mentioned our prepay, which is up year-over-year. Lower fertilizer prices helped. And I think there is a strong positive sentiment about a lower tax cuts for farmers that are causing farmers to have a little bit more positive sentiment than we've seen even in the November of last year. So we like the mood of 2017, at least the spring. And we think certainly our order book is showing that we're going to have a real solid first half of the year, both in wholesale but in retail as well. We did get more moisture in California. And there's going to -- we believe another 3 million acres of broad acre crops that are going to be put into production. Now, in the last two years or three years, California went early because it was dry. California most likely will be a little later, but overall, I think it's going to be better because there's going to be more production. And that's a very key market for us where we have a strong market presence. So net-net-net we like how 2017 is shaping up. UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: And based on your outlook for perhaps maybe a little more corn than you were thinking only a few months ago, do you think that there is maybe some catch-up necessary in amount of nitrogen that needs to get put down that maybe didn't go down in the fall, growers may have hedged thinking can maybe they're going to plant more beans. Where do you think we are in the amount of nitrogen that will be applied for this first half versus how much you've already sold? CHUCK MAGRO: We believe there could be some upside to the nitrogen applications because of that. Certainly in Western Canada, we didn't get a lot of nitrogen down and that's a high margin business for us than our retail business in Western Canada and so we're expecting a very good spring for nitrogen applications. And then you're exactly right, in the southern part of the US, right now, where we are rolling in the south, we're seeing excellent applications and really good orders. So we'll see, it's still a little early to get overly optimistic, but there is more upside I think than there is downside when we look at certainly the planning that we've looked at so far. STEVE BYRNE : And would you say weakness in pricing here recently is the result of (inaudible) coming on stream, maybe, and [Weaver] coming on stream and yet there is so more demand to come? CHUCK MAGRO: Yes. The weakness I think, it's there, but it's quite small. When I look at kind of the drivers, you've got China this time of year operating best report, 50%, exports last month were 200,000 tons, last year they were over 1 million tons at this time and we -- China was running in the [70s] in terms of on-stream time. So I think that nitrogen supply demand, I believe that the new capacity will come online, but I'm not sure it's going to impact the spring. There might be some consideration that's why maybe we saw a little bit of price reduction, but I think generally what we think is that there's going to be more strength going into the second quarter for nitrogen unless China does something different and then the seasonal softness will come in the second half of the year. But I actually think the first half of the year you're going to see -- could even see a little bit more strengthening in nitrogen pricing. STEVE BYRNE : Okay. I think we're about out of time. Thank you, Chuck, appreciate it. CHUCK MAGRO: Thank you.
